title: Power - justify power from force and velocity

content.question: Two objects, <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, of equal mass experience net forces that are graphed as functions of time in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The velocities of the two objects are graphed as functions of time in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. A student claims that at time <math alttext="t equals 4.0 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>0</mn><mo> </mo><mtext>s</mtext></math>, the instantaneous power being delivered to Object <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> is greater than the power being delivered to Object <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> by the net forces acting on each object. Which of the following identifies whether the claim is correct or incorrect and provides appropriate evidence to support the claim?

choices.label: The claim is correct. At <math alttext="t equals 4.0 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>, the slope of the velocity curve for Object <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>’s is greater than the slope of the velocity curve for Object <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>.

The claim is correct. At <math alttext="t equals 4.0 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>, the net force on Object <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> is greater than the net force on Object <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>.

The claim is correct. At <math alttext="t equals 4.0 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>, the product of the net force and velocity for Object <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> is greater than the product of the net force and velocity for Object <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>.

The claim is incorrect. The area under the force-time graph for Object <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> from <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> to <math alttext="t equals 4 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math> is less than the area for Object <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>.

content.answer: The claim is correct. At <math alttext="t equals 4.0 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>, the product of the net force and velocity for Object <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> is greater than the product of the net force and velocity for Object <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
